title: Lectures
text:
Evan’s Lectures

Incentives
Markets and Their Failures
Equity vs. Efficiency

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Recall our last class
We created a market for extra credit.

The outcome was efficient—we exhausted all gains from trade.


But was it fair?

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
A question of endowments
Some of you happened to be given an extra credit point.

Some of you didn’t.


Even though the market outcome maximized total surplus, who benefited depended entirely on those initial endowments.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
The fundamental distinction

Efficiency asks: How big is the pie?



Equity asks: How is the pie divided?



Failure to separate these is probably one of the biggest conceptual mistakes in policy today.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Today’s roadmap

Trends in inequality
What “fairness” means
Ideal redistribution (and why it’s impossible)
The costs of real-world redistribution
When distortions are actually good

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Efficiency

Whether the economy is set up to generate the maximum total benefits


Efficiency is about the size of the pie.


An efficient allocation leaves no gains from trade unexploited.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Equity

Whether the distribution of benefits is judged to be fair


Equity is about how the pie is divided.


Note: This is a normative judgment—outside economics per se.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Distortions

When policy drives a wedge between social value and private return


Distortions cause people to make decisions that don’t maximize total surplus.


They’re usually the cost of achieving a more equitable distribution.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Deadweight loss

The loss in total benefits that results from distortions


When we redistribute, the pie often shrinks.


Deadweight loss measures how much it shrinks.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Second best

The lowest-cost way to achieve a particular distribution


If we can’t achieve equity for free, what’s the most efficient way to get there?

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
US income inequality: The headline


Source: World Inequality Database. Shows share of national income going to top 10% vs bottom 50%.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
What happened?
From ~1980 onward:

Top 10% share rose from ~35% to ~45%
Bottom 50% share fell from ~20% to ~13%


The gains from economic growth went disproportionately to the top.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Another perspective: Top 1%
The top 1% now earns about 20% of all income.

In the 1970s, it was closer to 10%.



The very top has pulled away even from the rest of the top 10%.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Wealth inequality is even starker
Income: What you earn each year
Wealth: What you own (assets minus debts)

The top 1% owns roughly 30% of all wealth.


The bottom 50% owns about 2%.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
A global perspective


Data from World Inequality Report. Shows global income distribution by region.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
The elephant curve
Over the past 40 years, who gained the most globally?


The global middle class (especially China, India)
The global top 1%



Who gained the least?



The working and middle classes in rich countries.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Why does this matter?
Inequality affects:

Political stability
Social mobility
Health outcomes
Trust in institutions


But whether it’s a problem depends on your values.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
section: Let’s find out what you think
text:
Let’s find out what you think
I’m going to describe some scenarios.

For each one, tell me what the fair outcome is.


[Poll: pollev.com/e4e]

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Scenario 1: The shipwreck
You’re on a lifeboat with 10 others. You have 100 units of food.

Option A: Everyone gets 10 units
Option B: The person who can ration best distributes it (total consumed: 120 equivalent units due to efficiency)
Option C: Whoever grabbed it first keeps it


What’s fair?

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Scenario 2: The inheritance
A wealthy person dies. Should their children:

A: Inherit everything (property rights)
B: Inherit nothing—it goes to charity (equal opportunity)
C: Inherit some, with the rest taxed (compromise)


What’s fair?

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Scenario 3: The kidney
One kidney is available. Three patients need it:

A: A 25-year-old who will live 40 more years
B: A 65-year-old who invented a life-saving drug
C: Whoever has waited longest on the list


What’s fair?

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
The point
There’s no consensus on what “fair” means.

Different frameworks give different answers.


Let’s look at the main ones.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Utilitarianism

Maximize total well-being across all people.


Implication: Transfer resources until marginal utility is equalized.


If a dollar means more to a poor person than a rich person, transfer it.


Problem: Doesn’t care about distribution per se—only totals.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Rawlsian maximin

Maximize the well-being of the worst-off person.


John Rawls asked: What rules would you choose behind a “veil of ignorance”?


If you didn’t know your place in society, you’d protect the bottom.


Problem: Ignores everyone except the very worst off.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Libertarianism

Respect property rights and voluntary exchange.


Whatever distribution emerges from fair processes is fair.


Problem: Ignores how initial endowments were acquired.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Equality of opportunity

Everyone should have the same starting point.


Inequality of outcomes is okay if it results from fair competition.


Problem: Hard to define and achieve equal starting points.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Equality of outcomes

Everyone should end up with the same amount.


Problem: Eliminates incentives; practically impossible.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Where do you stand?
[Poll: Which framework resonates most with you?]


Utilitarian (maximize total well-being)
Rawlsian (protect the worst off)
Libertarian (respect property rights)
Equal opportunity
Equal outcomes

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
The economist’s role
Economics can’t tell you which framework is “right.”

That’s a normative judgment—a question of values.


But economics can tell you:

What are the costs of achieving different distributions?

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
A remarkable result
Suppose the market allocation differs from your preferred “fair” outcome.

Can we get to the fair outcome without losing efficiency?


Yes—in theory.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
The Second Welfare Theorem

Any efficient allocation can be achieved by:

Redistributing initial endowments
Then letting the market work



If we could just reshuffle who starts with what, markets would do the rest.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Back to our classroom market
Imagine I wanted to help students who most need the extra credit.

Ideal solution: Give the initial extra credit points to them instead.


Then let the market play out normally.


Efficient and equitable!

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
The catch
This requires lump-sum taxes and transfers.

Lump-sum means:

Pre-specified amounts
Do not depend on your behavior or choices



Like a fixed tax you pay regardless of what you do.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Why lump-sum works
If a tax doesn’t depend on your choices, it doesn’t distort them.

You face the same incentives as before—you just start with less money.



No deadweight loss. No distortion. Just redistribution.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
The problem
What could we actually tax in a lump-sum way?

We’d need to tax something immutable—that you can’t change.


One serious proposal: tax height.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Wait, really?
Mankiw & Weinzierl (2010) showed:

Taller people earn more on average
Height is (mostly) genetically determined
A height tax would be non-distortionary



“The case for taxing height is about as good as the case for taxing income.”



Nobody actually proposes this. But it illustrates the problem.

Reference: Mankiw & Weinzierl (2010). “The Optimal Taxation of Height.” American Economic Journal: Economic Policy.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Why we can’t do lump-sum
We can’t observe the things we’d need to observe:

Innate ability
Effort capacity
Future earnings potential


So we tax things we can observe: income, wealth, consumption.


But these depend on choices—so taxes distort behavior.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
A simple idea
Rich people have a lot of money.

Poor people need money.


Why not just tax the rich and give to the poor?

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
The behavioral response
We covered this in our lecture on incentives.

When you tax income, you change the return to working.


Higher taxes → work becomes less attractive → people work less.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Recall the Laffer curve

At some point, raising rates actually lowers revenue.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
The real cost
Even before we hit the peak, higher taxes cause:

Reduced labor supply
Less entrepreneurship
More tax avoidance


The tax base shrinks—so the pie gets smaller.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
The tradeoff

We can make the distribution more equal…
…but often at the cost of a smaller pie.


This is the fundamental equity-efficiency tradeoff.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
How big is this cost?
Remember the elasticity of taxable income?

Best estimates suggest it’s around 0.25.


Not zero—but not enormous either.



We can redistribute, but there’s a cost.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
An illustration with our workers
Let’s go back to our construction workers and content creators.

Suppose society decides it’s unfair that TikTokers might earn more than construction workers.


Policy: Tax TikTok earnings and subsidize construction wages.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
What happens?
The tax drives a wedge between what consumers pay and what creators receive.

Some content creators switch to construction work.


But wait—these are people whose comparative advantage is in TikToks!

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text: The distortion visualized

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
The math
Before the tax: \[P_H \cdot H_0 + P_T \cdot T_0 = \text{Total Value}\]

After the tax, people reallocate. But: \[P_H \cdot H_1 + P_T \cdot T_1 < P_H \cdot H_0 + P_T \cdot T_0\]



Total value produced has fallen—even though we collected tax revenue.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Why the loss?
We’ve shifted production to people who are relatively bad at it.

Content creators forced into construction produce fewer houses than real construction workers would.


Construction workers staying put don’t make up the difference.



Deadweight loss: The economy produces less than it could.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
section: What if we used lump-sum transfers?
text:
What if we used lump-sum transfers?
Suppose we could tax content creators a fixed amount—regardless of whether they work in TikTok or construction.

Then the tax doesn’t affect their work decisions.


No reallocation. No distortion. No deadweight loss.


But we can’t observe “being a content creator” independent of their choices.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Recall externalities
An externality is when your action affects others who aren’t part of the transaction.


Negative: Pollution, congestion, secondhand smoke
Positive: Vaccination, education

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
The problem with externalities
Without intervention, markets produce:

Too much of goods with negative externalities
Too little of goods with positive externalities


Prices don’t reflect the true social costs and benefits.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
The Pigouvian solution
Arthur Pigou’s insight: Tax negative externalities, subsidize positive ones.

A tax equal to the external cost makes people internalize the harm.



A distortion that corrects a market failure can increase efficiency.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Carbon tax example
Burning fossil fuels causes climate change.

A carbon tax makes polluters pay for this harm.


Result: Less pollution, and higher total surplus.



This is a “good” distortion—it fixes a broken price signal.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
The key insight
Distortions are costly when they push us away from efficiency.

But when markets are already failing, the right distortion can push us toward efficiency.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Public goods
Some goods can’t be provided by markets:

National defense
Basic research
Public health infrastructure


These require tax revenue to provide.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
The necessity of taxes
If we need taxes to fund public goods, we’ll have some distortion.

The goal isn’t to eliminate distortion—it’s to minimize it.



Raise the revenue you need in the least costly way possible.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Efficient taxation
Economic research suggests:

Broad bases, low rates minimize distortion
Tax things that are hard to change (land, consumption)
Avoid taxing things that are easy to move (capital, mobile workers)


This is why economists often prefer consumption taxes to income taxes.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Sometimes we can do both
In rare cases, we can increase both efficiency and equity:


Removing regulations that protect the wealthy (occupational licensing, zoning)
Fixing market failures that hurt the poor (predatory lending, pollution in poor neighborhoods)
Investing in human capital (education for disadvantaged kids)



These are win-wins—but they’re not always available.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
The hard cases
Most of the time, we face real tradeoffs.

More redistribution → more distortion → smaller pie.


The question isn’t whether to redistribute—it’s how much.



The answer depends on your values and the costs.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Key takeaways

Efficiency and equity are distinct—don’t conflate size with distribution



Fairness is normative—economics can’t tell you what’s fair




Ideal redistribution is impossible—lump-sum taxes aren’t feasible




Real redistribution has costs—distortions reduce total output




Sometimes distortions help—when correcting externalities

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Thinking like an economist
An economist holds both ideas in mind:


Markets are powerful tools for efficiency
Distribution matters and may require intervention




The goal is to understand the tradeoffs and quantify them.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text:
Next time
We’ll explore how economists actually measure the effects of policies.

How do we know if a policy worked?


The answer: Causation and experiments.

title: Equity vs. Efficiency
text: Questions?

title: Economics for Everyone | Spring 2026
text:
Course Description
Because modern economics puts such a heavy stress on technical rigor, the most interesting economic ideas are often buried behind abstract mathematical notation. Professors List and Rose will explore these big ideas without the math, making the beauty and power of economic thinking available to everyone.
We will discuss what it means to think like an economist, how you can use economic thinking to make the world a better place, and how economists think about today’s biggest issues, including what makes your rent get more expensive every year, why discrimination persists (and how to fix it), and how generative artificial intelligence will reshape the labor market.

title: Economics for Everyone | Spring 2026

Coursework

title: Incentives
text:
Recall our first principle

Economists believe that people optimize.


Optimization means people do their best given:

Their preferences
The constraints they face



Optimization also means people respond to incentives.

title: Incentives
text:
What is an incentive?
An incentive is anything that affects the payoffs of your choices.

Monetary incentives:

Wages, prices, taxes, fines



Non-monetary incentives:

Norms, reputation, emotions
Convenience, effort, time
Identity, social approval

title: Incentives
text:
Why incentives matter for policy
When you change incentives, people respond.

The impact of a policy change will almost always:

Not be as if the world stood still
Not be exactly what you predict



If you’re not careful, a policy might have the opposite effect of what you intended.

title: Incentives
text:
Key ideas for today

Behavioral response: Adjustments people make when incentives change


Strategic interactions: How others’ choices affect my incentives


Unintended consequences: When policies backfire due to unforeseen responses


Cognitive biases: Systematic departures from simple optimization

title: Incentives
text:
Thinking like an economist
Thinking like an economist means:

Predicting behavioral responses before policy
Measuring responses after policy
Designing better incentives based on what you learn

title: Incentives
text:
The naive view
Raise the tax rate a little…

…and you should collect more tax revenue.


But what might happen to the incomes of the highest earners?

title: Incentives
section: Top marginal tax rates in the US
text:
Top marginal tax rates in the US






Source: Wikipedia / Tax Foundation. Shows dramatic variation from 90%+ in 1950s to ~35-40% today.

title: Incentives
text:
Labor supply and taxes
As wages rise, people face a tradeoff:

Substitution effect: Higher wages make leisure more expensive → work more
Income effect: Higher wages mean you can afford more leisure → work less


Which dominates? It depends.

title: Incentives
text:
A thought experiment
Suppose you’re in charge of tax policy.

You raise the top tax rate from 40% to 50%.


What happens to tax revenue?

title: Incentives
text:
The Laffer curve intuition


At 0% tax: $0 revenue
At 100% tax: $0 revenue (why work?)
Somewhere in between: maximum revenue

title: Incentives
text:
The key insight

Revenue = Tax Rate × Tax Base


But the tax base is endogenous.


When rates rise, people may:

Work fewer hours
Shift income to other forms
Move to other jurisdictions
Engage in avoidance or evasion

title: Incentives
text:
What does the evidence say?
Best empirical estimates suggest behavioral responses are modest in the short run.

Saez, Slemrod & Giertz (2012):

Elasticity of taxable income ≈ 0.25
“Behavioral responses are not negligible, but not as large as some claim”


Reference: Saez, Slemrod, and Giertz (2012). “The Elasticity of Taxable Income with Respect to Marginal Tax Rates.” Journal of Economic Literature 50(1): 3-50.

title: Incentives
section: What does this imply for optimal rates?
text:
What does this imply for optimal rates?
The revenue-maximizing tax rate formula:

t* = 1 / (1 + e)


With e ≈ 0.25:

t* = 1 / 1.25 = 80%



Current US top rate (~37%) is well below this.


Higher rates would still raise revenue—though with efficiency costs.

title: Incentives
section: But some people are very responsive
text:
But some people are very responsive
European soccer players provide a striking example.

Kleven, Landais & Saez (2013) studied player mobility across 14 countries:

Foreign players: elasticity ≈ 1.0 (highly responsive)
Domestic players: elasticity ≈ 0.15 (less mobile)



Lower-tax countries attract the best talent.

Reference: Kleven, Landais, and Saez (2013). “Taxation and International Migration of Superstars: Evidence from the European Football Market.” American Economic Review 103(5): 1892-1924.

title: Incentives
text:
Spain’s “Beckham Law”
In 2004, Spain cut tax rates for foreign workers from 43% to 24%.


Graph is stylized/illustrative based on patterns from Kleven, Landais & Saez (2013), not exact reproduction.

title: Incentives
text:
The lesson
When people can move, tax incentives matter a lot.


Foreign players: highly mobile → big response
Domestic players: less mobile → small response



The size of behavioral responses depends on how easy it is to adjust.

title: Incentives
text:
An important clarification

This is not an argument against taxes.



It’s an argument that behavior matters.



Revenue effects depend on behavioral responses—we need to measure them.

title: Incentives
text:
Let’s play a game
I’m going to collect a number from everyone in the class.

Your job: Guess what the class’s average guess will be, divided by two.



Pick any number from 0 to 100
If the class average is 50, the winning guess is 25

title: Incentives
text:
Submit your guess
[PollEverywhere QR code here]

Ready? Go!

title: Incentives
text:
Discussion

What were your individual incentives?
What’s the “best” response?
What would perfectly rational players do?

title: Incentives
text:
Let’s play again
Now that you’ve thought about it…

[Play the game again]

title: Incentives
text:
The $20 bill auction
Here’s a $20 bill. I’m going to auction it off.

Rules:

Standard auction: highest bidder wins and pays their bid
But: The second-highest bidder also pays their bid (and gets nothing)



We’ll start at $1 and go up by $1 increments.

title: Incentives
text:
Let’s play
Who wants to bid $1?

title: Incentives
text:
Discussion
Think about what happened:


What were the strategic incentives at each point?




How did past bids affect future incentives?




What was the best approach from the start?

title: Incentives
text:
The key lesson

Each step was locally rational.



The outcome was globally terrible.



You don’t need irrational people to get insane outcomes—just the wrong rules.

title: Incentives
text:
Let’s play again
Knowing what you know now…

title: Incentives
text:
The fundamental insight
As you can see, incentives are complicated.

The most fundamental reason policy is tricky:

People respond to the incentive itself, not your objective.

title: Incentives
text:
This isn’t about bad intentions

People aren’t being malicious
They’re just playing the game you set up
The way they play depends on each other and their history

title: Incentives
text:
Goodhart’s Law

“When a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure.”


Examples:

Teaching to the test
Policing quotas
Corporate KPIs
Academic publishing (citations)

title: Incentives
text:
Soviet nail factory


A nail factory in Kuibyshev is given a production quota by number of nails.

What do you think happens?


Factory produced only tiny nails.

title: Incentives
text:
Soviet nail factory (continued)
The planners wise up. They switch to a quota by weight.

Now what happens?


Factory switched to producing only huge nails—as in the cartoon:

“Who needs such a nail?”
“That’s nothing! The main thing is we immediately fulfilled the plan for nails…”



No one ever made medium nails.

title: Incentives
text:
Ban the box
Many jurisdictions “banned the box”—employers can’t ask about criminal history on initial applications.

Intended effect: Help people with records get jobs.


But think like an economist: What might employers do instead?

title: Incentives
text:
Ban the box (continued)
Employers, unable to screen on records, used race as a proxy.

Discrimination against Black applicants increased.


The policy backfired—for the very people it was meant to help.

title: Incentives
text:
The evidence: Agan & Starr (2018)
Field experiment: ~15,000 fictitious job applications in NJ and NYC

Before BTB (at companies with “the box”):

White callback rate: 11.1%
Black callback rate: 10.9%
Gap: ~7% more callbacks for white applicants



After BTB (box removed):

White callback rate: 14.8%
Black callback rate: 10.3%
Gap: ~43% more callbacks for white applicants


Reference: Agan & Starr (2018). “Ban the Box, Criminal Records, and Racial Discrimination: A Field Experiment.” Quarterly Journal of Economics 133(1): 191-235.

title: Incentives
text:
A policy question
You want students to learn more. You have money for incentives.

Option A: Pay students for good test scores
Option B: Pay students for reading books


Which would you choose? Why?

title: Incentives
text:
The tradeoff
Problem with paying for test scores (outputs):

Students might not know how to improve
May encourage cheating
May distort effort toward test-taking skills


Paying for reading books (inputs):

Students know exactly what to do
Harder to game
Builds the skill you actually want

title: Incentives
text:
Evidence from Fryer (2011)
Roland Fryer ran experiments in multiple cities:


Pay for actions students can control, not outcomes they can’t.


Reference: Fryer (2011). “Financial Incentives and Student Achievement.” Quarterly Journal of Economics 126(4): 1755-1798.

title: Incentives
text:
People don’t always respond “rationally”
A final complication: people don’t always respond to incentives the way a simple model predicts.

Economists have documented many cognitive or behavioral biases.

title: Incentives
text:
Inertia and defaults
When given choices, people tend to stick with the default option.

Example: 401(k) enrollment

Opt-in default: ~50% participation
Opt-out default: ~90% participation



Same options, very different outcomes.

Reference: Madrian & Shea (2001). “The Power of Suggestion: Inertia in 401(k) Participation and Savings Behavior.” Quarterly Journal of Economics.

title: Incentives
text:
Is this really a “bias”?
Important question: Why might people rationally stick with the default?


Information costs (the default might be a good recommendation)
Time costs (switching takes effort)
Uncertainty (maybe the default-setter knows something)



Important to separate positive (what people do) from normative (what they should do).

title: Incentives
text:
Loss aversion
People feel losses more strongly than equivalent gains.


Losing $100 feels worse than gaining $100 feels good
Ratio is roughly 2:1



Implications:

Framing matters (gains vs. losses)
People may reject gambles that are favorable on average
Status quo bias

title: Incentives
text:
The Asian Disease Problem
A disease outbreak will kill 600 people. You must choose a response:

The name comes from Tversky & Kahneman’s original 1981 paper, which described “an unusual Asian disease” as a hypothetical scenario. The framing was arbitrary—meant to invoke an unfamiliar disease without domestic political implications.


Frame A (lives saved):

Program A: 200 people will be saved
Program B: 1/3 chance all 600 saved, 2/3 chance no one saved



What do most people choose?

title: Incentives
text:
The Asian Disease Problem (continued)
Now consider a different framing:

Frame B (lives lost):

Program C: 400 people will die
Program D: 1/3 chance no one dies, 2/3 chance all 600 die



What do most people choose now?

title: Incentives
text:
The result
Frame A (gains): 72% choose the certain option (Program A)
Frame B (losses): 78% choose the risky option (Program D)

But A = C and B = D!



When facing gains, people are risk-averse.
When facing losses, people are risk-seeking.



(The name comes from the original 1981 paper’s hypothetical “unusual Asian disease”—chosen to be unfamiliar and politically neutral.)

Reference: Tversky & Kahneman (1981). “The Framing of Decisions and the Psychology of Choice.” Science.

title: Incentives
text:
Present bias
Question 1: Would you rather have…

A: $100 today
B: $110 next week


Question 2: Would you rather have…

C: $100 in 52 weeks
D: $110 in 53 weeks

title: Incentives
text:
Present bias (continued)
Most people choose A (money now) but D (more money later).

But wait—both questions have the same tradeoff: $10 for one week of waiting!


This is time-inconsistent behavior.



People overweight immediate rewards relative to future rewards.

title: Incentives
text:
Present bias in action
Why present bias matters for policy:


People under-save for retirement
People procrastinate on exercise, healthy eating
Students cram instead of studying gradually



Policy responses:

Commitment devices (automatic savings plans)
Deadlines and penalties
“Cooling off” periods for major purchases


Reference: Laibson (1997). “Golden Eggs and Hyperbolic Discounting.” Quarterly Journal of Economics.

title: Incentives
text:
Mental accounting
You receive $1,000. How much would you spend on something fun?

Scenario A: It’s a tax refund
Scenario B: It’s from your regular paycheck


Most people spend more in Scenario A—but why?


Money is fungible—a dollar is a dollar.



People treat money differently depending on where it “comes from.”


Reference: Thaler (1999). “Mental Accounting Matters.” Journal of Behavioral Decision Making.

title: Incentives
text:
The sunk cost fallacy
You paid $50 for a concert ticket. It’s raining, you feel sick, and you don’t want to go.

Should you go?


Economically: The $50 is gone either way. Only future costs and benefits matter.


In practice: Most people go—to “not waste” the $50.



People continue investing because of what they’ve already spent, not what they’ll gain.

title: Incentives
text:
What we learned today
Incentives determine:

What people try
What they ignore
What they distort
How they adapt over time

title: Incentives
text:
The bottom line

Policies don’t operate on a fixed world—they change the world they operate on.


Thinking like an economist means recognizing this when you design and evaluate policy.

title: Incentives
text:
Looking ahead
Failing to account for behavioral responses can lead to disaster.

But doing so appropriately can be the key to managing everything—from your own life to the federal government.

title: Incentives
text: Questions?

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Today’s Journey
Markets are one of the most powerful institutions humans have ever created.

Today we’ll explore:

Why markets are so good at delivering benefits
How prices coordinate complex economic activity
The gains from specialization
When and why markets fail
What we can do about those failures

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Key Ideas for Today
Gains from trade: The benefits buyers and sellers get from exchange

Comparative advantage: The returns to focusing on what you’re relatively better at


Markets as surplus maximizers: Under ideal conditions, markets deliver maximum total benefits


Market failures: Forces that prevent markets from achieving their potential

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Our Very Own Market
I’m going to allocate half the class one point of extra credit.

You will be the sellers in this market.


The other half of the class will be the buyers.

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Your Task
If you are a seller:

Report the lowest price (in dollars) at which you would give up your extra credit point.


If you are a buyer:

Report the highest price (in dollars) at which you would buy an extra credit point.



Take a moment to reflect. What is that point really worth to you?

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Submit Your Answer
[Poll link: pollev.com/e4e]

title: Markets and Their Failures
text: Let’s See What We Got

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Discussion

Who wants to trade at the equilibrium price?



Do the traders benefit? How much?




What about the people who didn’t trade?




What role does the price play here?

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Willingness to Pay and Accept
Consider a market for a single good (say, toasters).

Sellers each have a willingness to accept (WTA)

The smallest amount they’d take to part with the good



Buyers each have a willingness to pay (WTP)

The highest amount they’d pay to acquire the good

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Surplus: The Gains from Trade
When a buyer pays less than their WTP:

They get consumer surplus = WTP - Price


When a seller receives more than their WTA:

They get producer surplus = Price - WTA



Total surplus = Consumer surplus + Producer surplus

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
What Happens at Equilibrium?
At the equilibrium price \(p\):


Every seller with WTA ≤ \(p\) has sold
Every buyer with WTP ≥ \(p\) has bought



The only remaining sellers want more than \(p\).
The only remaining buyers will pay less than \(p\).



No more gains from trade exist!

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
The First Welfare Theorem

Under certain conditions, competitive markets automatically maximize total surplus.


This is remarkable. No central planner needed.


Just people pursuing their own interests, guided by prices.


Adam Smith called this the “invisible hand.”

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Prices as Signals
Here’s something remarkable about the equilibrium price:

For sellers: The price reflects the marginal cost of production

The cost of producing one more unit



For buyers: The price reflects the marginal benefit of consumption

The value of consuming one more unit



At equilibrium: Marginal cost = Marginal benefit = Price

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Why This Matters
The price tells producers: “This is what society values an extra unit at.”

The price tells consumers: “This is what it costs society to make an extra unit.”



Prices coordinate decisions across millions of people who will never meet.



No one needs to know the whole picture. The price contains the information.

title: Markets and Their Failures
section: Price Discovery in the Real World
text:
Price Discovery in the Real World
Real markets are messy. Prices don’t appear by magic.

If price is too high: Excess supply

Sellers undercut each other to secure trades



If price is too low: Excess demand

Buyers offer premiums to secure goods



Market pressures push toward equilibrium.

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Examples of Price Discovery
Retail inventory management

Prices drop when shelves are full
Prices rise when stock runs low


Auctions

eBay, art markets, Treasury bonds
Price emerges from competitive bidding



Entry and exit

High profits → new firms enter → prices fall
Losses → firms exit → prices rise

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
A Deeper Point
You might think: supply and demand determine price.

But in practice, prices are discovered through experimentation.


In this sense: prices determine supply and demand.


Prices are signals that coordinate behavior.

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Case Study: Gold
What determines how much gold gets mined?

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Gold: When Demand Surges
When demand for gold increases:


Price rises




Mining operations that were unprofitable become profitable




Supply expands




The price signal coordinated this response—no central planner required.

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Two Types of Workers
Consider an economy with two groups of workers:

Construction workers — tend to be better at building houses


Content creators — tend to be better at making TikToks


Both groups can produce either good, but with different abilities.

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
The Production Possibilities Frontier
We can illustrate what each group can produce with a PPF.

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
The Trade-Off
The PPF shows trade-offs: more houses means fewer TikToks.

The curve bows outward because of increasing opportunity cost.



The first TikToks come from the most social-media-savvy workers. More TikToks require pulling less suited workers.

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Comparing Opportunity Costs
At any point, the slope of the PPF tells us the opportunity cost.

Let’s compare the two groups at the same level of TikTok production…

title: Markets and Their Failures
text: Comparative Advantage

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
What This Means
For construction workers, TikToks are expensive — each one costs many houses.

For content creators, TikToks are cheap — each one costs few houses.



Construction workers have comparative advantage in houses.
Content creators have comparative advantage in TikToks.

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
The Key Insight
Comparative advantage is about relative costs, not absolute ability.

Even if construction workers were better at both activities, content creators still have lower opportunity cost for TikToks.


Each group should specialize in their comparative advantage.

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
But How Much to Specialize?
Comparative advantage tells us what to focus on.

But how do groups know how much of each good to produce?


Prices answer this question.

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Market Prices
Suppose houses and TikToks trade in markets:

Houses: $200,000 each
TikToks: $50 each


Where on the PPF should each group locate?

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
The Optimal Point
Each group should produce where their opportunity cost equals the price ratio.

At that point, shifting production either way would reduce total income.

title: Markets and Their Failures
text: Finding the Optimum

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
This Allocation Maximizes Total Value
At these optimal points, total value produced is maximized.


The tangent lines have the same slope (the price ratio)
No reallocation could increase total output value




Given prices, this is the best we can do.

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
The Magic of Prices
Workers don’t need to know each other’s abilities.

They don’t need to coordinate with anyone.


They just respond to prices — and the economy specializes efficiently.

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
The Invisible Hand

Prices guide each person to their comparative advantage—automatically.


No central planner needed.


Prices contain the information needed to coordinate production across millions of people.

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Remember Those “Conditions”?
The First Welfare Theorem says markets maximize surplus…

…under certain conditions.


When these conditions fail, we get market failures.


Let’s explore the three most important ones.

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
The Market for “Lemons”
Imagine you’re buying a used car.


Some used cars are great (“peaches”)
Some are terrible (“lemons”)



The seller knows which type they have. You don’t.

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
What Happens?
You’re willing to pay the average value.

But sellers of good cars won’t accept that—it’s below their car’s worth.


So good cars exit the market.


Only lemons remain!



Adverse selection: The market unravels because of information asymmetry.


Reference: Akerlof, G. (1970). “The Market for Lemons.” Quarterly Journal of Economics.

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Let’s Play: Lemons Edition
Let’s revisit our extra credit market.

Sellers: I’m going to randomly assign you to real or fake credits.


Check your email/phone now—I’ve sent half of you a message saying “REAL” and half “FAKE.”


(If you didn’t get a message, your credit is FAKE.)

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Lemons Game: The Rules
Sellers: You know if your credit is real (worth 1 point) or fake (worth 0).

Buyers: You don’t know which sellers have real credits.


Sellers: What’s your WTA now?
Buyers: What’s your WTP now?


Submit your answers!

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Discussion: Lemons Game

What happened to the market?
Did good credits trade?
How does this compare to used cars, health insurance, job markets?

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Real-World Responses
How do markets cope with information problems?


Warranties and guarantees
Reputation systems (Yelp, eBay ratings)
Certification (inspections, credentials)
Regulation (disclosure requirements)

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
What’s an Externality?
An externality is a cost or benefit that affects someone not involved in the transaction.

Negative externality: Your action harms others

Factory pollution, secondhand smoke, loud music



Positive externality: Your action helps others

Vaccinations, education, beautiful gardens

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Why Externalities Cause Failure
When you buy gas, you pay for:

The cost of extracting and refining oil
The gas station’s markup


You don’t pay for:

Air pollution affecting your neighbors
Climate change affecting everyone




The market price is “wrong”—it doesn’t reflect the true social cost.

title: Markets and Their Failures
text: The Result

title: Markets and Their Failures
section: Too Much of a Bad Thing
text:
Too Much of a Bad Thing
With negative externalities:

Private cost < Social cost
Market produces too much of the good
Total surplus is not maximized



Pollution is the classic example. The market “fails” because prices don’t include all costs.

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Let’s Play: Externalities Edition
Back to our credit market.

New rule: Each credit point sold reduces the value of ALL other credits by 5%.


If 5 trades happen, every credit (traded or not) is worth only 75% of a point.


This is like a curve: the more points out there, the less each one helps your grade.

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Externalities Game: Think About It
You’re a buyer. You still want a credit point.

But when you buy one, you make everyone else’s credits less valuable.


Do you consider that cost when deciding to trade?


Should that cost affect whether the trade happens?

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Discussion: Externality Game

How many trades are privately beneficial?
How many trades are socially beneficial (counting harm to others)?
Who bears the cost of your trade?
How might we fix this?

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Perfect Competition Assumption
The welfare theorem assumes price-taking behavior:

No individual buyer or seller can affect the market price.


But what if one seller controls most of the supply?

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Monopoly Pricing
A monopolist can set the price.

They’ll charge more than the competitive price.


Result:

Some beneficial trades don’t happen
Total surplus decreases
The monopolist captures more surplus, but overall pie shrinks

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Let’s Play: Monopoly Edition
New game structure:

I’ll sell all the credits to one student at the earlier market price.


That student becomes the monopolist and sells to everyone else.


Monopolist: What price will you charge?

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Discussion: Monopoly Game

What price did the monopolist choose?
How many trades happened compared to the competitive market?
Who won? Who lost?

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Real-World Market Power

Tech giants: Google, Apple, Amazon, Meta
Pharmaceuticals: Patent-protected drugs
Utilities: Natural monopolies (water, electricity)
Local markets: The only hospital in a rural area

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
The Role of Government
When markets fail, government intervention can help:

Information problems:

Disclosure requirements
Consumer protection laws
Professional licensing



Externalities:

Taxes on harmful activities (carbon tax)
Subsidies for beneficial activities (education)
Regulation (emission standards)

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Government Responses (continued)
Market power:

Antitrust enforcement
Price regulation for utilities
Promoting competition



But government intervention has its own costs and can fail too. More on this later in the course.

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
The Coase Theorem
Sometimes private bargaining can solve externalities.

Coase’s insight: If property rights are clear and transaction costs are low, people negotiate to the efficient outcome.

Reference: Coase, R. (1960). “The Problem of Social Cost.” Journal of Law and Economics.

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Coase Example
Factory pollutes, harms nearby residents.


If residents have right to clean air → factory pays them
If factory has right to pollute → residents pay factory



Either way, they negotiate to the efficient level of pollution!

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
When Coase Works (and Doesn’t)


Works well:

Few parties
Harm is measurable
Clear property rights


Doesn’t work:

Many parties (climate)
Hard to measure harm
High transaction costs

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
What We Learned Today

Markets maximize surplus by exhausting gains from trade



Prices are signals that coordinate without central planning




Comparative advantage makes specialization valuable




Markets can fail: info asymmetry, externalities, market power




Failures can be addressed: government, bargaining, institutions

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
The Bottom Line

A market is a wonderful thing.


Thinking like an economist means:

Understanding when markets work their magic
Recognizing when they don’t
Designing institutions to help them succeed

title: Markets and Their Failures
text:
Next Time
Equity vs. Efficiency

Is maximizing surplus enough?
What about fairness?
The fundamental tradeoffs in economic policy
